RAF chiefs are reportedly planning on banning women from wearing skirts on parade in a bid to make the service more inclusive. 
Top brass are said to want women wearing trousers on military parades on barracks and during public displays and events. 
The move is thought to have come about on the back of a reported increase in trans-gender personnel. 
One source told The Sun : “We have men who want to live as women, women who want to live as men and personnel who do not identify with any gender. Read More The Duchess of Cambridge and Prince Phillip poses with RAF personnel (Photo: PA Archive) 
“It’s about including people and encouraging diversity.” 
But the move has infuriated many servicewomen who are reportedly “livid”. The move aims to make the service more inclusive (Photo: AFP) 
One said: “We’ve all been told woman can no longer wear skirts on parade. 
“Everyone’s livid. We’ve been wearing skirts since World War II. It feels like political correctness. The world’s going mad.” Read More Some members of the RAF believe it is 'political correctness gone mad' (Photo: Getty Images Europe) 
An RAF spokesman said: “Uniform regulations, including dress for formal parades, are regularly reviewed. 
“No decisions have been made to make any changes.” Like us on Facebook
